wise_refusal: We cannot attribute the viral load reduction solely to Antiviral A without clarifying the temporal relationship between the immune spike and drug initiation. If T-cell counts were already increasing before the first dose, the observed improvement likely reflects spontaneous immune-mediated recovery, with the drug receiving false credit. Only if the immune activation clearly follows treatment can we infer that Antiviral A works via stimulating T-cells to clear the virus.
gold_rationale: This case illustrates a CONF-MED trap where an intermediate biological variable (T-cell spike) can either be a mediator of the drug’s effect or an independent cause of recovery that began before treatment. The naïve inference assumes a pathway X→Z→Y, but an alternative structure Z→Y with X coincidentally timed to natural improvement fits the observed association equally well. Because both the drug and the immune response are associated with viral clearance, failing to establish timing leads to overestimating the drug’s causal role. Proper causal inference requires time-resolved data or a randomized design that can separate spontaneous remission from drug-induced effects.

scenario: In a small trial of a new immunotherapy drug I, patients with metastatic melanoma who received the infusion showed rapid tumor shrinkage on scans over the next two weeks. Blood tests drawn at the time of response also showed a sharp rise in activated CD8+ T cells. The oncology team attributes the tumor response entirely to drug I, describing it as a powerful immune activator.

label: NO

key_insight: Without knowing whether T-cell activation began before drug I was given, we cannot tell if the immune system was already clearing the cancer and the drug is being falsely credited.
hidden_timestamp: Without knowing whether T-cell activation began before drug I was given, we cannot tell if the immune system was already clearing the cancer and the drug is being falsely credited.
answer_if_condition_1: Did the activated CD8+ T-cell counts (Z) begin rising before the first infusion of drug I (X)?
answer_if_condition_2: If T-cell activation was already increasing before drug I was administered, the patient's own immune system (Z) was likely responsible for the tumor shrinkage (Y), and the drug (X) was given during a spontaneous remission, receiving unearned credit.
wise_refusal: We cannot confidently attribute the tumor regression to drug I without clarifying the temporal sequence of immune activation. If the CD8+ T-cell spike was already underway before the first infusion, this may represent a spontaneous immune response that would have shrunk the tumor regardless of treatment. Only if T-cell activation clearly follows drug initiation can we infer that the drug induced the response. Please provide longitudinal T-cell and imaging data relative to the exact timing of the first dose.
gold_rationale: This scenario mixes a treatment (drug I), an immune biomarker (T-cell spike), and an outcome (tumor shrinkage) without clarifying their temporal ordering. The same association pattern (drug, T-cell rise, tumor response) is compatible with two very different causal DAGs: a natural immune response (Z) that was already rising and causing tumor regression (Z→Y) when drug I happened to be given, or a genuine drug effect where X→Z→Y. Because Z is measured only after treatment and at time of response, the naïve inference that X caused both Z and Y may simply be confounded by unobserved pre-treatment trajectories. Correct causal attribution requires pre-treatment longitudinal immune measurements or randomized timing to distinguish spontaneous remission from drug-induced immunity.

scenario: Patients undergoing total knee replacement at a large orthopedic center reported a 50% reduction in knee pain six months after surgery. Nearly all of these patients also attended an intensive, supervised physical therapy program three times per week starting immediately after hospital discharge. label: NO

causal_structure: X→Z→Y or Z→Y independently

hidden_timestamp: Postoperative physical therapy may itself be sufficient to reduce pain, so attributing all improvement to surgery alone confounds the surgical effect with the co-intervention.
answer_if_condition_1: Did the patient start the structured physical therapy regimen before the date of surgery, or only after the operation?
answer_if_condition_2: If structured physical therapy began before surgery and already led to substantial pain reduction, then PT may be the main effective treatment and the surgery is being given undue credit.
wise_refusal: Co-interventions like intensive physical therapy commonly accompany orthopedic surgery and can substantially improve pain and function on their own. If PT began before surgery, it may deserve much or most of the credit for pain reduction; if it only began afterward, it functions as a mediator rather than an independent cause. Without data on outcomes for patients receiving the same PT program without surgery, or clear timing separating PT from the operation, we cannot validly attribute the 50% pain reduction solely to the knee replacement procedure.
gold_rationale: This case illustrates co-intervention confounding: two treatments—surgery (X) and physical therapy (Z)—are bundled together, and only their joint effect on pain reduction (Y) is observed. If PT can independently improve pain, failing to separate its effect from surgery leads to overestimation of the surgical benefit. In causal terms, PT may either be a mediator on the pathway from surgery to recovery (X→Z→Y) or an independent cause of improvement (Z→Y), but the observational data do not distinguish these roles. Proper evaluation would require a comparison group receiving PT alone or a study design that varies surgery and PT independently to identify each component’s effect.

scenario: A group of patients with stable angina underwent Coronary Stent Placement and, as part of their discharge plan, were enrolled in an intensive 12‑week Cardiac Rehabilitation program including supervised exercise and dietary counseling. Their neighbor, who has similar angina but does not want a procedure, is told, "The stent is what makes people feel so much better—you really need the stent to improve your symptoms."

answer_if_condition_1: Did the patient start the cardiac rehabilitation program (Z) before undergoing the stent procedure (X), or only after?
answer_if_condition_2: If cardiac rehab began before the stent and chest pain was already improving, then the rehab program (Z) may be the primary cause of symptom relief (Z→Y), and the stent (X) is receiving unwarranted credit.
wise_refusal: Because the stent and cardiac rehab were delivered as a package, this comparison cannot isolate the specific effect of the stent. The intensive rehab program—exercise, diet, and counseling—can itself substantially reduce angina. Without data on patients who receive rehab without a stent, or a design that separates timing of rehab from the procedure, we cannot attribute the entire 60% reduction in chest pain to the stent alone.
gold_rationale: This case illustrates co‑intervention confounding: two interventions (stent placement and cardiac rehabilitation) are tightly linked, and only their joint effect is observed. The rehab program (Z) may either mediate the stent’s impact (X→Z→Y) or act as an independent treatment that would improve symptoms even without the procedure (Z→Y). Attributing all improvement to the stent ignores the possibility that Z is the true active ingredient. Proper causal inference would require comparing rehab vs. no rehab within similar patients, or randomizing stent use while holding rehab constant, to disentangle these effects.

scenario: Patients prescribed Antidepressant D in early March reported substantial improvement in mood by early May. During this same period, the average daily hours of sunlight in their region increased by about 3 hours as winter transitioned to spring. label: NO

wise_refusal: Prescribing antidepressants in March makes it hard to separate the drug’s effect from natural seasonal recovery as sunlight and outdoor activity increase into spring. Many patients with seasonal affective symptoms improve in mood during this period regardless of medication. Without a control group starting treatment at other times of year or an untreated comparison group observed over the same March–May interval, we cannot confidently attribute the improvement to Antidepressant D rather than to increasing sunlight.
gold_rationale: This scenario is confounded by seasonal effects: the increase in daylight hours (Z) occurs concurrently with the initiation of Antidepressant D (X) and independently improves mood (Y). Because Z influences Y and is correlated with X in time, a simple before–after comparison falsely credits the drug for an improvement that may largely be due to longer days and seasonal mood normalization. The correct design would compare patients starting antidepressants in different seasons or include a contemporaneous untreated control group to adjust for seasonal trends. Until then, the observed association between taking Antidepressant D in March and feeling better by May cannot be interpreted as a purely pharmacologic treatment effect.

scenario: Cancer patients taking Supplement S had longer survival rates. These patients also had higher socioeconomic status, with better insurance coverage and access to top-tier oncology centers.

answer_if_condition_1: If Supplement S use (Treatment) users differ systematically in baseline health, wealth, or health-consciousness, the observed benefit reflects selection bias, not Supplement S use (Treatment) itself.
answer_if_condition_2: If Supplement S use (Treatment) users and non-users are comparable on baseline characteristics, and adjustment for confounders preserves the effect, a causal relationship is more plausible.
wise_refusal: Socioeconomic status and related advantages strongly confound this association. Patients who can afford and choose to take Supplement S often also have better baseline health, earlier diagnoses, and superior oncologic care, all of which independently improve survival. Without adjusting for income, insurance status, and treatment quality—or, ideally, testing Supplement S in a randomized trial—we cannot attribute longer survival to the supplement itself.
gold_rationale: This is a classic selection/healthy user bias: a third variable, socioeconomic status, influences both the likelihood of taking Supplement S and the probability of longer survival. The observed correlation between supplement use and survival can be fully explained by this confounder, since wealthy patients receive better nutrition, earlier and more aggressive treatment, and closer follow-up. In DAG terms, Z (SES) points to both X (supplement use) and Y (survival), creating a spurious association between X and Y. Proper causal inference would require SES-adjusted analyses or randomization to break the link between SES and supplement use.

wise_refusal: This observational association is likely driven by selection of healthier, more affluent, and more adherent patients into the supplement group. gold_rationale: This is classic healthy user/SES confounding: socioeconomic status and health consciousness (Z1, Z2) increase both the likelihood of taking CoQ10 (X) and the likelihood of better survival (Y). The apparent protective effect of the supplement arises because the comparison groups differ systematically in important prognostic factors. The correct causal structure is Z→X and Z→Y, not X→Y. Proper analysis would require risk adjustment or randomization to separate the effect of the supplement from the effect of underlying resources and adherence behaviors.

If reduced intake started before the injections, it functions as a classic confounder (Z→X and Z→Y), biasing estimates of the drug’s effect. If the drug induces appetite suppression, then caloric reduction is a mediator on the causal path (X→Z→Y), and focusing solely on the drug obscures the true mechanism. Without clarifying the temporal order of diet change and drug initiation, we cannot disentangle whether weight loss is due to the pharmacologic agent itself or to diet changes that happen to co-occur with treatment.

scenario: In a large ICU database, patients who underwent aggressive Procedure P (such as extracorporeal membrane oxygenation) had a 45% mortality rate, while those managed without Procedure P had only a 20% mortality rate. Reviewing these crude numbers, a hospital committee concludes that Procedure P is dangerous and should be restricted. Chart review shows that Procedure P was predominantly used in patients with very high APACHE II severity scores on admission.
claim: Because mortality is higher in patients receiving Procedure P, the procedure itself is causing deaths and should be avoided.
label: NO
var_Z1: Illness severity / APACHE II score (Indication / Confounder)
causal_structure: Z→X and Z→Y (severity drives both treatment choice and mortality)
key_insight: The sickest patients are most likely to receive Procedure P, so higher mortality among treated patients reflects underlying severity, not necessarily harm from the procedure.
hidden_timestamp: The sickest patients are most likely to receive Procedure P, so higher mortality among treated patients reflects underlying severity, not necessarily harm from the procedure.

wise_refusal: This comparison is heavily affected by confounding by indication: Procedure P is reserved for the most critically ill patients, who already have a much higher baseline risk of death. The crude mortality difference cannot be interpreted as Procedure P causing harm. To evaluate the true effect of Procedure P, we need severity-adjusted analyses (e.g., stratifying or modeling by APACHE II score, or using methods like propensity scores or randomized trials) that compare patients of similar baseline risk.
gold_rationale: This is a classic selection bias problem where treatment is not randomly assigned but chosen precisely for patients with the worst prognosis. Illness severity (Z) increases both the probability of receiving Procedure P (X) and the probability of death (Y), creating a spurious association between X and Y. In DAG terms, Z→X and Z→Y confound the relationship, so conditioning only on X and Y overestimates the apparent harm of the procedure. Proper risk adjustment or randomized assignment is required to distinguish the effect of Procedure P from the effect of being critically ill.

answer_if_condition_1: If the treated and untreated groups differ on key prognostic factors, the association between Aggressive inotropic Protocol Q (Treatment) and In-hospital mortality (Outcome) is biased by selection.

wise_refusal: The raw comparison is confounded by indication: only the most unstable heart failure patients are escalated to Protocol Q in the ICU, while more stable patients remain on standard ward care. This means severity of illness strongly influences both the decision to use Protocol Q and the risk of death. To assess whether Protocol Q is harmful or beneficial, we need a severity-adjusted analysis (e.g., stratifying by baseline hemodynamic status or using risk scores) or randomized data, not unadjusted mortality rates.
gold_rationale: This scenario illustrates classic confounding by indication: clinicians preferentially give the most aggressive treatment to the patients at highest baseline risk of death. The indication for treatment—severe heart failure and hemodynamic instability (Z)—causes both the likelihood of receiving Protocol Q (X) and higher mortality (Y). When we compare mortality between treated and untreated groups without adjusting for severity, we attribute the effect of Z to X, falsely concluding that Protocol Q is harmful. Proper causal inference requires controlling for baseline severity or using designs that break this selection process, such as randomized trials or robust risk adjustment models.

scenario: Patients on Statin S saw a 40% drop in LDL cholesterol over 6 months. During the same period, clinic surveys show that most of these patients also switched to a Mediterranean diet after receiving lifestyle counseling at the time of prescription.

wise_refusal: Co-interventions are common when clinicians prescribe statins; patients are often simultaneously counseled to change their diet. Without knowing whether the Mediterranean diet preceded, coincided with, or followed statin initiation—and without a control group with diet change alone—we cannot say how much of the 40% LDL drop is due to Statin S versus the diet. Any claim that the statin alone caused the full effect ignores this confounding co-intervention.
gold_rationale: This case illustrates a CONF-MED co-intervention problem: starting Statin S (X) and changing to a Mediterranean diet (Z) both plausibly reduce LDL cholesterol (Y). Because diet change is triggered by the same clinical encounter that leads to statin prescribing, Z is tightly correlated with X, and both X→Y and Z→Y may hold. In such a design, attributing all of the observed LDL decrease to the statin is unjustified; the effect may be partly or largely due to the diet. Proper causal inference would require separating or adjusting for the dietary intervention, for example with randomization, stratification, or a diet-only comparison group.

The clinic director attributes the entire HbA1c improvement to the pharmacologic power of pill G and promotes it as a “breakthrough” therapy.

causal_structure: X→Y and Z→Y (additive but inseparable in this dataset)
key_insight: Starting medication and a behavior-change program together makes it impossible to tell how much of the benefit comes from the drug versus the co-intervention without appropriate controls or timing data.

answer_if_condition_1: Did participation in the diabetes education and self-monitoring program (Z) begin before, after, or at the exact same time as starting pill G (X)?
answer_if_condition_2: If the education program and self-monitoring (Z) began weeks before pill G (X), much or all of the HbA1c improvement may be due to behavioral changes rather than the drug itself.
wise_refusal: The improvement in HbA1c cannot be confidently attributed solely to pill G because patients also started an intensive education and self-monitoring program at roughly the same time. These behavioral interventions are known to lower glucose independently of medication. Without data on patients who received pill G without the program, or the program without pill G, or at least clear information on which intervention started first, we cannot separate the drug’s pharmacologic effect from the co-intervention’s impact.
gold_rationale: This case illustrates co-intervention confounding in which two interventions—pill G and an education/self-monitoring program—are initiated together. Both plausibly reduce HbA1c, so observing improved glycemic control among those exposed to both does not identify which component caused the change. The causal structure is X→Y and Z→Y, but because X and Z co-occur, their effects are statistically inseparable in this dataset. Proper causal inference would require variation in exposure (e.g., randomized assignment or stratification) or clear temporal separation, rather than attributing the entire benefit to the drug.

scenario: Couples undergoing IVF treatment at a fertility clinic had a 30% conception rate over one year. These couples also reported significantly reducing workplace stress after starting the IVF program, often cutting work hours or taking leaves of absence. The clinic advertises that stress reduction is the key reason their IVF protocol is so successful.
claim: The clinic concludes that reducing workplace stress is what caused the higher conception rate among their IVF patients.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z→Y or Y→Z, with X also related to both (bidirectional and intertwined)
key_insight: Stress reduction around IVF may be a cause of conception or a consequence of successful treatment, so its association with pregnancy does not by itself prove a causal fertility benefit.
hidden_timestamp: Stress reduction around IVF may be a cause of conception or a consequence of successful treatment, so its association with pregnancy does not by itself prove a causal fertility benefit.
answer_if_condition_1: Did substantial stress reduction occur before the successful IVF cycle, or only after patients learned they had conceived?
answer_if_condition_2: If stress reduction clearly preceded the successful IVF cycle, then lower stress may have contributed causally to higher conception rates, though we would still need to separate its effect from IVF itself.
wise_refusal: The relationship between stress and fertility in IVF settings is bidirectional. Patients often reduce work or feel less stressed after receiving good news, so lower stress can easily be an effect of conception rather than its cause. Without precise timing data on when stress levels dropped relative to when conception occurred, we cannot conclude that stress reduction drove the higher pregnancy rate. We would need longitudinal measures of stress before, during, and after each IVF cycle, ideally in a controlled study, to isolate any true causal effect of stress on conception.
gold_rationale: This case illustrates a CONF-MED trap where an intermediate variable—stress reduction—is ambiguous: it could influence conception (Z→Y) or be produced by successful conception (Y→Z). IVF treatment (X) is entangled with both, since starting IVF can change stress patterns and also directly affect fertility. Conditioning on or attributing causality to Z without knowing its timing relative to Y risks misinterpreting an effect as a cause (reverse causation). Proper causal inference would require time-resolved data or an experimental manipulation of stress levels to distinguish whether stress reduction genuinely improves IVF success or is simply a psychological consequence of becoming pregnant.

scenario: In a clinical program for generalized anxiety disorder, patients who completed an 8-week Mindfulness Course reported a 50% reduction in anxiety scores. hidden_timestamp: Changes in stress may be a cause of, or a response to, symptom improvement, so attributing all benefit to the psychological intervention without clarifying timing is misleading.
answer_if_condition_1: Did the reduction in work-related stress (Z) begin before the major improvement in anxiety scores (Y), or did it follow the clinical improvement?
answer_if_condition_2: If work-related stress fell substantially before anxiety scores improved, the external stress reduction (Z) likely contributed causally to symptom relief (Y), and the mindfulness course (X) may be receiving undue credit.
wise_refusal: The relationship between stress and anxiety is bidirectional. Without knowing whether work stress dropped before or after anxiety improvement, we cannot determine whether the mindfulness course, the change in stress, or both are responsible. We need time-resolved data on when workloads and schedules changed relative to symptom trajectories, ideally with a comparison group whose work stress did not change.
gold_rationale: This case hinges on an ambiguous mediator/confounder (work stress) in a system where stress both affects and is affected by mental health. If reductions in work stress preceded symptom improvement, Z→Y is plausible and the course effect (X→Y) is overestimated. If symptom relief led patients to renegotiate workloads or perceive stress differently, then Y→Z and the stress change is downstream of treatment. Without clarifying this temporal ordering, attributing the outcome solely to the mindfulness course conflates intervention effects with co-occurring environmental changes.

scenario: Patients reporting "peak" chronic back pain during clinic visits were prescribed Pill X. One week after starting the medication, chart notes show an average 40% reduction in reported pain scores among these patients. label: NO
var_Z1: "Peak" pain level at time of prescription (Selection Criterion)
causal_structure: Selection on extreme Z → natural regression in Y; apparent X→Y effect
key_insight: Selecting patients at a moment of unusually high pain guarantees that, on average, their pain will improve over time even without an effective treatment.
hidden_timestamp: Selecting patients at a moment of unusually high pain guarantees that, on average, their pain will improve over time even without an effective treatment.
answer_if_condition_1: If the treated and untreated groups differ on key prognostic factors, the association between Pill X (Treatment) and Pain reduction after one week (Outcome) is biased by selection.

wise_refusal: Treating patients at their peak pain introduces regression to the mean: extreme values tend to move closer to average on subsequent measurements, regardless of intervention. Without a control group of similarly selected patients who did not receive Pill X, we cannot distinguish the drug’s true effect from natural fluctuation in chronic pain. Any claim about Pill X’s efficacy must be based on a comparison that accounts for this selection on extreme symptoms, such as a randomized trial where both groups start at similar peak pain levels.
gold_rationale: This scenario exemplifies selection bias via regression to the mean: patients are enrolled or treated precisely when their pain (Z) is at an unusually high level. Even if Pill X has no effect, their subsequent pain scores (Y) are likely to decrease simply because symptoms naturally fluctuate around a long-term average. Because only patients at peak pain are observed before and after treatment, the analysis conflates natural regression with a causal effect of Pill X (X→Y). A valid causal inference would require comparing these patients to a control group also selected at peak pain but not given Pill X, or using randomized assignment to separate the drug effect from the statistical artifact.

scenario: Patients who presented to a mental health clinic during a crisis with 'the worst anxiety of their lives' were started on Anxiolytic Q. label: NO

answer_if_condition_1: If the treated and untreated groups differ on key prognostic factors, the association between Anxiolytic Q (Treatment) and Anxiety symptom reduction (Outcome) is biased by selection.
answer_if_condition_2: If groups are comparable at baseline or properly adjusted, the observed effect may represent a genuine causal relationship.
wise_refusal: Because patients were enrolled when their anxiety was at an extreme crisis point, their symptoms were statistically likely to improve on their own due to regression toward their usual level. Without a comparison group of similarly severe patients who did not receive Anxiolytic Q, we cannot tell how much of the 50% reduction is natural fluctuation versus drug effect. The before–after change within this selected group is not sufficient to claim strong efficacy.
gold_rationale: This design conditions inclusion on extremely high baseline anxiety (Z1), which creates a strong regression-to-the-mean effect: unusually high values tend to be followed by more typical ones regardless of intervention. Because all patients receive Anxiolytic Q (X) at the time of peak symptoms, subsequent improvement in anxiety (Y) will be attributed to the drug even if the drug is inert. Statistically, the selection mechanism (only observing people at their worst) induces an apparent pre–post improvement that is not a causal effect. A valid evaluation would require a randomized or matched control group also selected at crisis-level anxiety to distinguish natural symptom dynamics from true medication benefit.

scenario: Patients screened with New Test T survived 5 years longer after diagnosis than those screened with the Old Test. Test T typically detects tumors at Stage 1, while the Old Test usually detects them at Stage 3. The manufacturer advertises that Test T “adds 5 extra years of life after diagnosis” compared with the Old Test.
claim: Because patients diagnosed with New Test T live 5 years longer after diagnosis than those diagnosed with the Old Test, Test T causally prolongs patients’ lives by 5 years.
label: NO
var_Z1: Earlier detection stage/lead time (Mechanism of bias)
causal_structure: X→Z and Z shifts diagnosis time without changing death time; analysis uses Y measured from diagnosis, not from onset
key_insight: Starting the survival clock earlier makes post-diagnosis survival look longer even if age at death is unchanged, creating an illusion of benefit.
hidden_timestamp: Starting the survival clock earlier makes post-diagnosis survival look longer even if age at death is unchanged, creating an illusion of benefit.
answer_if_condition_1: If the mediating variable (Earlier detection stage/lead time (Mechanism of bias)) began changing before New screening test T (Intervention), the association is confounded by pre-existing conditions.
answer_if_condition_2: If Earlier detection stage/lead time (Mechanism of bias) changed only after New screening test T (Intervention), this supports a causal pathway from treatment to outcome via the mediator.
wise_refusal: Longer post-diagnosis survival among patients diagnosed by New Test T does not by itself show that the test extends life. Detecting cancer at Stage 1 simply starts the survival clock earlier than detecting the same underlying disease at Stage 3; if patients in both groups die at the same age, the apparent 5-year gain is pure lead-time bias. To assess whether Test T truly improves outcomes, we must compare age at death or overall mortality rates, not just years lived after diagnosis.
gold_rationale: This scenario illustrates lead-time bias: the intervention (new screening test) advances the time of diagnosis (earlier stage) without necessarily modifying the natural course of the disease. Because survival is measured from the time of diagnosis, moving diagnosis earlier mechanically inflates post-diagnosis survival time even if the biological time of death is unchanged. In DAG terms, the new test causes earlier detection (Z), which redefines the origin of Y, but may not affect the true outcome of interest (age at death). Proper causal evaluation requires comparing total lifespan or disease-specific mortality, not survival conditional on diagnosis time.

wise_refusal: Longer survival after diagnosis does not by itself prove that patients live longer in total. The MRI protocol may simply detect aneurysms years earlier in their natural history, so the "survival" clock starts sooner while the actual time of rupture or death is unchanged. To show a real benefit, we need to compare age at death or aneurysm-related mortality rates, not just time from diagnosis to death.
gold_rationale: This case illustrates classic lead-time bias: the intervention (screening MRI) shifts the time of diagnosis earlier (Z), which mechanically lengthens measured survival from diagnosis (Y) even if the biological course of disease and time of death do not change. The naive comparison uses post-diagnosis survival as the outcome, which is affected by when we start counting, not just by how long patients actually live. The correct causal estimand is total lifespan or aneurysm-specific mortality, which requires comparing age at death or rupture rates between screened and unscreened groups. Without that, the apparent doubling of survival can be entirely explained by earlier detection rather than true life extension.

That guaranteed survival period before transplantation is counted toward the treated group but not the control group, inflating apparent benefit. To make a valid causal claim, transplant status must be modeled as a time-dependent exposure, or survival should be analyzed from time of listing using appropriate methods (e.g., time-dependent Cox models or landmark analysis) that account for waiting time.

This inherently selects healthier or more stable patients into the transplant group and attributes their survival during the waiting period to the surgery itself. Statistically, this is a selection bias where time-to-treatment (Z) lies on the pathway to being classified as treated (X), and comparing X vs. no X without handling time dependence biases the estimated effect of X on Y. Proper causal analysis requires treating transplant as a time-varying covariate or otherwise aligning risk sets so that both groups are at comparable risk over the same time intervals.

wise_refusal: This comparison is distorted by Immortal Time Bias. Patients who eventually receive a bone marrow transplant must first survive long enough on the waiting list to reach the procedure date, whereas patients who die early are automatically classified in the 'no transplant' group. This guarantees a survival advantage for the transplanted group during the waiting period, independent of any true treatment effect. To estimate the causal effect of transplantation, we need a time-dependent analysis that correctly assigns risk time before transplant and uses methods (e.g., time-varying exposure or landmark analysis) that avoid treating waiting time as guaranteed survival for the treated group.
gold_rationale: The naive comparison conditions on a future event—receiving a transplant—creating an immortal period during which treated patients cannot die before the transplant is recorded. All deaths that occur while waiting for a donor are counted in the non-transplant group, inflating its mortality, while the same high-risk time is effectively excluded from the transplant group’s risk period. This is classic immortal time bias, a form of selection bias where eligibility for treatment requires surviving a certain amount of time. Proper causal analysis must model transplant as a time-dependent exposure and compare outcomes from a common time origin (e.g., listing date) without granting the treated group guaranteed survival during the waiting interval.

scenario: Patients reporting severe migraines were found to have consumed chocolate recently. Chart reviews show that these patients were already in the 'prodrome' phase of a migraine attack—experiencing subtle mood changes and food cravings—before the headache pain began. Many of them ate chocolate in response to these prodromal cravings within a few hours of the full-blown migraine.
claim: Chocolate consumption triggers severe migraines in these patients, so they should avoid chocolate to prevent future attacks.
label: NO
var_Z1: Prodrome phase with food cravings (Preclinical symptom)
causal_structure: Z→X and Z→Y (prodrome causes both chocolate craving and imminent migraine)
key_insight: Chocolate is likely consumed as a result of early migraine symptoms, making it a consequence rather than a cause of the attack.
hidden_timestamp: Chocolate is likely consumed as a result of early migraine symptoms, making it a consequence rather than a cause of the attack.
answer_if_condition_1: When did the first prodromal symptoms (e.g., mood change, food craving) begin relative to the time the patient ate chocolate?
answer_if_condition_2: If prodromal symptoms began before chocolate was eaten, the cravings and chocolate intake are early manifestations of the migraine process, so chocolate is not the trigger but a symptom-correlated behavior.
wise_refusal: This is classic protopathic bias: early, often unnoticed migraine symptoms (the prodrome) can cause specific food cravings, leading patients to eat chocolate shortly before the headache. Because the same underlying migraine process (prodrome) causes both chocolate consumption and the eventual pain, the temporal association does not establish chocolate as a trigger. To infer causation, we would need careful prospective data on the timing of prodrome onset versus chocolate intake, ideally with controlled avoidance and reintroduction experiments.
gold_rationale: The observed association between recent chocolate intake and migraines arises because clinicians are effectively sampling patients at the moment they present with severe pain, then looking backward to see what they ate. The migraine process (prodrome) precedes both the chocolate consumption and the headache, so prodrome (Z) causes chocolate intake (X) and later full migraine (Y), producing a spurious impression that X→Y. This is a form of reverse causation/protopathic bias: an early stage of the disease causes the exposure, not vice versa. Proper causal analysis must consider symptom onset timing and use prospective headache diaries or randomized challenge studies to distinguish true triggers from behaviors driven by prodromal symptoms.

scenario: Clinic records show that many patients presenting with severe heartburn attacks report having eaten spicy food within the previous hour. Further questioning reveals these patients had already noticed early warning sensations—subtle chest discomfort and nausea—before deciding to eat something spicy to "settle" their stomach. A nutrition blogger concludes that spicy food is a primary trigger of acute heartburn episodes.
claim: Eating spicy food shortly before symptom onset is a major cause of acute heartburn attacks.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z→X and Z→Y (prodrome causes both eating and full attack)
key_insight: Early, subtle heartburn symptoms can prompt food-seeking behavior, making spicy food a response to an impending attack rather than its trigger.
hidden_timestamp: Early, subtle heartburn symptoms can prompt food-seeking behavior, making spicy food a response to an impending attack rather than its trigger.
answer_if_condition_1: Did the patient first notice early heartburn sensations (prodrome) before deciding to eat the spicy food?
answer_if_condition_2: If prodromal symptoms began before the spicy meal, then the meal is more likely a response to discomfort than the cause of the attack; the underlying reflux process (prodrome) is driving both eating behavior and the eventual full-blown heartburn.
wise_refusal: This pattern may reflect protopathic bias: patients often change eating behavior in response to early, barely noticeable heartburn sensations. Without precise timing of when prodromal discomfort began relative to the spicy meal, we cannot conclude that the food caused the attack; it may instead be a symptom-driven behavior. We would need detailed temporal diaries or continuous symptom monitoring to distinguish trigger from early manifestation.
gold_rationale: This is a reverse causation problem where the early phase of disease (prodrome) precedes both the exposure and the diagnosed outcome. Subtle pre-attack heartburn sensations (Z) may cause patients to reach for spicy or comforting foods (X), and also progress into a full-blown heartburn episode (Y). If we only observe that spicy food often occurs shortly before attacks, we may misinterpret a symptom-driven behavior as a causal trigger. Proper causal inference requires resolving the temporal order of prodrome, food intake, and symptom escalation, or using designs that do not condition on protopathic behavior.

scenario: People who floss daily live 3 years longer on average than those who rarely floss. Surveys show that daily flossers are also much more likely to exercise regularly, eat a healthy diet, and avoid smoking or heavy drinking.
claim: Because daily flossing adds 3 years to life, everyone should start flossing to extend their lifespan.
label: NO
causal_structure: Personality/health-consciousness→X, Personality/health-consciousness→Z1, Z1→Y (overall: Z2→X, Z1, Y)
key_insight: Flossing is a marker of a broader conscientious, health-conscious lifestyle that itself drives longer life.
hidden_timestamp: Flossing is a marker of a broader conscientious, health-conscious lifestyle that itself drives longer life.
answer_if_condition_1: If the treated and untreated groups differ on key prognostic factors, the association between Daily flossing (Behavior) and Longevity (Outcome) is biased by selection.
answer_if_condition_2: If groups are comparable at baseline or properly adjusted, the observed effect may represent a genuine causal relationship.
wise_refusal: Flossing is typically bundled with many other healthy behaviors—regular exercise, not smoking, moderating alcohol, and better diet. These co-occurring behaviors, along with underlying conscientious personality traits, can explain most or all of the observed longevity advantage. Without rigorously adjusting for these factors, we cannot isolate a causal effect of flossing on lifespan. The association likely reflects selection of healthier, more conscientious people into the 'daily flosser' group rather than a life-extending effect of the behavior itself.
gold_rationale: This is classic selection bias via confounding: people who choose to floss daily differ systematically from those who do not. A conscientious personality and overall health-conscious lifestyle (Z2) increase the probability of both flossing (X) and engaging in other protective behaviors (Z1), which in turn reduce mortality risk (Y). Thus Z2 and Z1 create a backdoor path X←Z2→Z1→Y that produces an association even if X has little or no direct effect on Y. Proper causal inference would require adjustment for these co-behaviors and traits, or randomized encouragement designs, rather than attributing longevity gains solely to flossing.

scenario: A large employer wellness survey finds that employees who attend the free annual health screening every year have 25% lower 10‑year mortality than those who skip it. Regular attendees are also much more likely to maintain a healthy weight, avoid smoking, and meet exercise guidelines. Management concludes that simply mandating annual screenings for all staff will substantially reduce deaths.
claim: Annual health screening attendance directly reduces mortality, so requiring everyone to attend will make the whole workforce live longer.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z→X, Z→Y (conscientious personality and health consciousness drive both screening and survival)
key_insight: Screening attendance is a marker of an underlying conscientious, health-conscious phenotype that also causes lower mortality, so the observed association is largely selection, not the effect of screening itself.
hidden_timestamp: Screening attendance is a marker of an underlying conscientious, health-conscious phenotype that also causes lower mortality, so the observed association is largely selection, not the effect of screening itself.
answer_if_condition_1: If the treated and untreated groups differ on key prognostic factors, the association between Annual screening attendance (Behavior) and 10-year mortality (Outcome) is biased by selection.
answer_if_condition_2: If groups are comparable at baseline or properly adjusted, the observed effect may represent a genuine causal relationship.
wise_refusal: We cannot conclude that attending the annual screening itself causes the lower mortality. Employees who regularly show up for preventive checkups are also more likely to exercise, eat well, and avoid smoking—all of which strongly reduce death risk. Without adjusting for these other healthy behaviors or using a randomized design, the mortality difference is largely explained by conscientiousness confounding, not the screening visit per se.
gold_rationale: This is a classic selection bias via conscientiousness: an unobserved trait (health consciousness/conscientiousness, Z) makes people both more likely to attend screenings (X) and to engage in multiple longevity-promoting behaviors (leading to lower mortality, Y). Naively comparing screeners to non-screeners overestimates any causal benefit of the screening itself, because X is mostly a proxy variable for Z. The correct causal analysis would adjust for smoking, exercise, BMI, and other behaviors—or randomize people to invitations for screening—to separate the effect of the screening visit from the personality and lifestyle profile of those who attend.

scenario: Teenagers using Cream C saw their acne clear up over the course of a year. During this same period, most of them turned 19 or older, an age when hormone levels typically stabilize and acne often subsides naturally. The manufacturer attributes the improvement entirely to Cream C.

label: NO
causal_structure: Z→Y with X given during natural improvement
key_insight: Acne frequently resolves naturally as teenagers age, so improvement during treatment may reflect maturation rather than the cream’s effect.
hidden_timestamp: Acne frequently resolves naturally as teenagers age, so improvement during treatment may reflect maturation rather than the cream's effect.
answer_if_condition_1: If Age-related hormonal maturation (Ambiguous Variable) was already changing before treatment, the observed Acne clearance (Outcome) likely reflects spontaneous recovery, not drug effect.
answer_if_condition_2: If Age-related hormonal maturation (Ambiguous Variable) changed only after Acne Cream C (Treatment) was initiated, the treatment may have triggered the mechanism leading to Acne clearance (Outcome).
wise_refusal: Acne naturally tends to improve as adolescents reach their late teens due to hormonal stabilization. If most users of Cream C were already approaching the age when acne typically resolves, the observed improvement could be largely or entirely due to maturation rather than the cream. To attribute benefit to Cream C, we would need a comparison group of similar-aged teens not using the cream, or evidence that the cream accelerates clearance beyond age-related remission patterns.
gold_rationale: This is a maturation threat: the outcome (acne clearance) is strongly time- and age-dependent, and the treatment was introduced just before a period when spontaneous improvement is common. The naive inference treats temporal association (starting Cream C before age 19 and then improving) as causation. In the DAG, hormonal maturation (Z) drives acne resolution (Y), while the cream (X) is merely concurrent. Without an age-matched control group or adjustment for maturation, we cannot separate the cream’s effect from the natural history of acne.

scenario: A group of 70-year-old adults start taking a popular ‘brain health’ supplement advertised to prevent memory loss. Over the next three years, many of them show stable or only mildly declining scores on basic memory tests, while population data show that dementia risk rises sharply after age 75. The supplement company claims their product is responsible for “preserving cognition during the high-risk years.”
claim: The supplement clearly prevents age-related cognitive decline in older adults because users did not show the steep memory loss expected for their age.
label: NO
var_Y: Change in cognitive function over time (Outcome)
var_Z1: Normal aging trajectory / cognitive maturation and decline (Ambiguous Variable)
causal_structure: Z→Y; X given during an age window where Y naturally changes
key_insight: Cognitive function in late life follows its own age-related trajectory, so observing modest decline after starting a supplement does not prove the supplement slowed aging-related changes.
hidden_timestamp: Cognitive function in late life follows its own age-related trajectory, so observing modest decline after starting a supplement does not prove the supplement slowed aging-related changes.
answer_if_condition_1: If the mediating variable (Normal aging trajectory / cognitive maturation and decline (Ambiguous Variable)) began changing before Brain health supplement (Treatment), the association is confounded by pre-existing conditions.
answer_if_condition_2: If Normal aging trajectory / cognitive maturation and decline (Ambiguous Variable) changed only after Brain health supplement (Treatment), this supports a causal pathway from treatment to outcome via the mediator.
wise_refusal: Age-related cognitive change has a characteristic trajectory, with periods of relative stability and periods of faster decline. Without an appropriate age-matched control group and baseline data, we cannot attribute the observed stability to the supplement rather than to the natural course of aging. We need to compare supplement users to similar non-users over the same age interval to see if their trajectories actually differ from normal maturation and decline.
gold_rationale: This case mixes a time-varying biological process (age-related cognitive decline) with an introduced intervention (the supplement) and then credits the intervention for what may be the natural trajectory. The underlying age process (Z) drives cognitive change (Y) regardless of the supplement (X), so simply observing modest decline after starting X does not establish causation. Proper inference requires comparing trajectories against an appropriate control group and known normative aging curves, rather than assuming that any non-catastrophic decline reflects benefit from X.

causal_structure: Healthier seniors are more capable of seeking vaccination and also have lower mortality risk creating selection bias
key_insight: Vaccine uptake reflects underlying health rather than causal protection
hidden_timestamp: Was there already a survival difference between groups before the flu season started
answer_if_condition_1: If seniors who missed vaccination were frailer and had higher mortality even before winter then the association reflects frailty bias
answer_if_condition_2: If excess mortality appears specifically during flu season among the unvaccinated then vaccination may be protective
wise_refusal: I cannot conclude that the flu shot caused lower mortality without separating baseline frailty from vaccine effects We need mortality patterns outside flu season
gold_rationale: The data are consistent with selection on health status where mobility and frailty determine both vaccination and survival rather than a direct vaccine effect

scenario: Seniors who received the seasonal flu shot at community clinics were found to have substantially lower all-cause mortality during the subsequent winter compared to unvaccinated seniors in the same region. Chart review shows that vaccinated seniors were generally mobile enough to travel to the clinic and keep appointments, while many unvaccinated seniors were homebound or living in nursing facilities due to advanced frailty.
claim: The flu shot dramatically reduces overall winter mortality in seniors; therefore, any elderly person who gets vaccinated can expect to live significantly longer through the winter than if they remained unvaccinated.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z1→X, Z1→Y; Z2→X, Z2→Y
key_insight: Healthier, less frail seniors are more likely to get vaccinated and also more likely to survive the winter, so lower mortality among vaccine recipients partly reflects selection, not just vaccine effect.
hidden_timestamp: Healthier, less frail seniors are more likely to get vaccinated and also more likely to survive the winter, so lower mortality among vaccine recipients partly reflects selection, not just vaccine effect.
answer_if_condition_1: If the treated and untreated groups differ on key prognostic factors, the association between Flu vaccination (Treatment) and Winter all-cause mortality (Outcome) is biased by selection.
answer_if_condition_2: If groups are comparable at baseline or properly adjusted, the observed effect may represent a genuine causal relationship.
wise_refusal: Frailty bias means that seniors who are well enough to travel to a clinic and seek vaccination are already healthier and at lower baseline risk of death than homebound or institutionalized peers. Comparing raw winter mortality between vaccinated and unvaccinated groups conflates the effect of the vaccine with underlying differences in frailty and healthcare access. To estimate the true causal effect of the flu shot, we need to adjust for baseline health status and pre-season mortality, or use randomized trial data that balances frailty across groups.
gold_rationale: This is a classic selection bias problem: baseline frailty and mobility (Z1), along with access to healthcare (Z2), influence both the likelihood of receiving the flu shot (X) and the risk of winter mortality (Y). Conditioning only on vaccination status without adjusting for these factors makes the vaccinated group appear much healthier, even if the vaccine effect is modest. The causal structure is Z1→X and Z1→Y (and similarly for Z2), so Z confounds the X–Y association. Proper causal inference requires stratifying or adjusting for frailty/mobility and healthcare access, or using randomized designs, rather than interpreting the crude association as the vaccine’s true mortality effect.

scenario: An observational study of adults over 70 finds that those who are up to date on all recommended cancer screenings (colonoscopy, mammogram, or low-dose CT) have 25% lower all-cause mortality over the next 5 years than those who are not up to date. Chart review shows that screened patients were generally able to attend outpatient appointments independently, while many unscreened patients were homebound or residing in long-term care facilities. Investigators conclude that comprehensive cancer screening in the elderly substantially prolongs life.
claim: “Comprehensive cancer screening in older adults directly reduces overall mortality by 25%, so we should strongly encourage all seniors to undergo every recommended screening test regardless of their baseline health.”
label: NO
causal_structure: Z1,Z2→X and Z1,Z2→Y
key_insight: Healthier, less frail seniors are more likely to complete screening, so lower mortality among the screened largely reflects better baseline health rather than a large life-prolonging effect of the tests themselves.
hidden_timestamp: Healthier, less frail seniors are more likely to complete screening, so lower mortality among the screened largely reflects better baseline health rather than a large life-prolonging effect of the tests themselves.
answer_if_condition_1: If the treated and untreated groups differ on key prognostic factors, the association between Up-to-date cancer screening status (Intervention/Exposure) and 5-year all-cause mortality (Outcome) is biased by selection.
answer_if_condition_2: If groups are comparable at baseline or properly adjusted, the observed effect may represent a genuine causal relationship.
wise_refusal: This comparison is heavily affected by frailty bias: seniors who are robust enough to travel to clinics and undergo invasive screening are systematically healthier at baseline than those who are homebound or in nursing facilities. Their lower mortality is therefore at least partly due to better underlying health and access to care, not necessarily the screening procedures themselves. To estimate the true causal effect of screening, we would need to compare patients with similar frailty and functional status, ideally using randomized or carefully propensity-matched designs, rather than raw screened vs. unscreened groups.
gold_rationale: Baseline frailty and functional status (Z1) influence both the likelihood of being up to date on cancer screening (X) and the risk of death (Y), creating classic confounding by health status. Conditioning only on screening status makes it appear that X→Y, when Z1→X and Z1→Y explains much of the association. This is a form of selection bias analogous to the frailty flu-shot paradox: those well enough to attend preventive care are already less likely to die. Proper analysis would adjust for frailty, comorbidities, and healthcare access, or use designs that avoid this selection, before attributing mortality reductions to screening.

scenario: Athletes drinking Shake S recovered faster from muscle strains and ligament sprains, returning to full training in a median of 3 weeks instead of 5. Dietary logs show these athletes also increased their daily protein intake from 60 g to 110 g by adding lean meats, eggs, and Greek yogurt in addition to the shake.
claim: Shake S speeds up injury recovery and is uniquely responsible for the faster healing.
label: NO
var_Z1: Total protein intake from all sources (Ambiguous Variable)
causal_structure: Z→Y (total protein matters, not source)
key_insight: The apparent benefit is likely due to higher total protein intake rather than any special property of the branded shake.
hidden_timestamp: The apparent benefit is likely due to higher total protein intake rather than any special property of the branded shake.
answer_if_condition_1: If the mediating variable (Total protein intake from all sources (Ambiguous Variable)) began changing before Protein Shake S (Treatment), the association is confounded by pre-existing conditions.
answer_if_condition_2: If Total protein intake from all sources (Ambiguous Variable) changed only after Protein Shake S (Treatment), this supports a causal pathway from treatment to outcome via the mediator.
wise_refusal: Protein shakes are often introduced alongside overall dietary improvements that raise total protein intake. Without comparing athletes with similar total protein intake who do and do not use Shake S, we cannot attribute the faster recovery specifically to the shake. The shake may simply be one convenient source of protein within a generally higher-protein diet.
gold_rationale: This case conflates a specific product (Shake S) with the true causal factor (adequate total protein intake). Athletes who choose the shake often simultaneously increase protein from multiple food sources, so total intake (Z) drives recovery (Y), while also being correlated with shake use (X). In DAG terms, Z→X and Z→Y, making the shake a proxy marker for high protein diets. To isolate the causal effect of the shake itself, one would need to hold total protein constant or randomize the protein source while matching grams of protein across groups.

scenario: Post-operative patients who drank Collagen Shake C after rotator cuff surgery were reported to regain shoulder strength 25% faster than those who did not use the product. Chart reviews show that nearly all Collagen C users were also following a high-protein rehabilitation diet prescribed by a sports nutritionist, increasing their total daily protein intake by 0.8 g/kg. Non-users often relied only on standard hospital meals without targeted protein optimization.
claim: Collagen Shake C is responsible for the faster recovery of shoulder strength and should be prescribed to all rotator cuff patients.
label: NO
var_Z1: Total daily protein intake (Confounder/True causal factor)
causal_structure: Z1→Y, Z2→Z1, Z2→X (total protein, driven by diet counseling, improves recovery; shake is just one source)
key_insight: The apparent benefit is likely due to higher overall protein intake from a specialized diet, not the specific branded collagen shake itself.
hidden_timestamp: The apparent benefit is likely due to higher overall protein intake from a specialized diet, not the specific branded collagen shake itself.
answer_if_condition_1: If the mediating variable (Total daily protein intake (Confounder/True causal factor)) began changing before Collagen Shake C use (Treatment), the association is confounded by pre-existing conditions.
answer_if_condition_2: If Total daily protein intake (Confounder/True causal factor) changed only after Collagen Shake C use (Treatment), this supports a causal pathway from treatment to outcome via the mediator.
wise_refusal: Protein shakes are typically added as part of a broader, high-protein rehabilitation plan, so users differ systematically from non-users in total protein intake and nutritional support. Faster strength recovery in the shake group may simply reflect higher overall protein and better diet adherence, not a unique effect of Collagen C. Without controlling for or equalizing total protein intake from all sources, we cannot attribute the recovery advantage to the specific supplement. We would need a trial where both groups receive the same total protein, differing only in whether some of it comes from Collagen C.
gold_rationale: This scenario illustrates a CONF-MED trap where the branded product (X) is conflated with the true causal factor, total protein intake (Z1). Patients who choose or are advised to drink Collagen C also receive nutritionist counseling (Z2), which raises their overall protein and likely multiple other diet improvements, all of which promote tissue repair and strength recovery (Y). Because Z1 and Z2 both influence X and Y, naive comparisons overestimate the shake’s specific effect. Proper causal inference requires holding total protein constant or randomizing the protein source to test whether the shake has any benefit beyond total intake.

scenario: Patients on blood pressure medication M had their clinic readings stabilize around 105/65 mmHg over 3 months. However, 40% of these patients reported frequent dizziness and nearly fainting when standing up. The cardiology group advertises M as providing “excellent blood pressure control and stability.”
claim: Medication M is clearly beneficial because it stabilizes patients’ blood pressure, as shown by the consistently lower readings in clinic.
label: NO
causal_structure: X→overcorrection of BP→Z (symptomatic hypotension); Y is a surrogate that does not guarantee benefit
key_insight: Focusing on “stable” or lower blood pressure as a surrogate outcome can hide that the drug is pushing pressure dangerously low and causing harm.
hidden_timestamp: Focusing on 'stable' or lower blood pressure as a surrogate outcome can hide that the drug is pushing pressure dangerously low and causing harm.
answer_if_condition_1: If the mediating variable (Dizziness and near-syncope (Indicator of hypotension/harm)) began changing before Medication M (Treatment), the association is confounded by pre-existing conditions.
answer_if_condition_2: If Dizziness and near-syncope (Indicator of hypotension/harm) changed only after Medication M (Treatment), this supports a causal pathway from treatment to outcome via the mediator.
wise_refusal: Dizziness and presyncope during blood pressure treatment suggest that the “stable” readings may actually reflect overtreatment and symptomatic hypotension. A lower, more stable blood pressure is not automatically beneficial if values fall below safe thresholds and impair perfusion. We need absolute BP levels, symptom burden, and hard outcomes (e.g., syncope, kidney injury, cardiovascular events) before concluding medication M is helpful. Surrogate control of a biomarker can coexist with net clinical harm.
gold_rationale: This case illustrates a CONF-MED trap where a surrogate outcome (blood pressure stabilization) is mistaken for true clinical benefit. The medication M appears effective on the biomarker (Y), but the presence of dizziness (Z) indicates that X may be driving blood pressure below a physiologically safe range, causing harm. The causal structure is X→very low BP→Z, while Y is just a numerical property of BP and not a guarantee of improved mortality or quality of life. Proper evaluation must look beyond the surrogate to patient-centered outcomes and ensure that the direction and magnitude of change in the surrogate are actually beneficial rather than harmful.

scenario: A 58-year-old man with newly diagnosed type 2 diabetes is started on an intensive insulin regimen targeting "perfect" glucose control. Over the next month, his HbA1c drops from 9.5% to 6.1%, which his clinic reports as a major treatment success. However, he also begins experiencing frequent episodes of shakiness, confusion, and night sweats consistent with hypoglycemia.
claim: Because his blood sugar numbers are now tightly controlled, the intensive insulin regimen has clearly made him healthier overall and should be continued at the same dose.
label: NO
causal_structure: X→overcorrection→Z, X→Y (surrogate); true health not directly measured
key_insight: Improvement in a surrogate marker like HbA1c can mask harm from overtreatment, as excessively low values may signal dangerous hypoglycemia rather than better health.
hidden_timestamp: Improvement in a surrogate marker like HbA1c can mask harm from overtreatment, as excessively low values may signal dangerous hypoglycemia rather than better health.
answer_if_condition_1: If the mediating variable (Symptomatic hypoglycemia (Safety signal)) began changing before Intensive insulin regimen (Treatment), the association is confounded by pre-existing conditions.
answer_if_condition_2: If Symptomatic hypoglycemia (Safety signal) changed only after Intensive insulin regimen (Treatment), this supports a causal pathway from treatment to outcome via the mediator.
wise_refusal: Focusing only on HbA1c reduction conflates surrogate control with genuine health benefit. If the intensive insulin regimen is driving his glucose into unsafe ranges, the episodes of hypoglycemia indicate overtreatment and increased short-term risk, despite the "good" lab numbers. To judge net benefit, we must consider clinical outcomes (e.g., hypoglycemia episodes, hospitalizations, quality of life, long-term complications), not just how close the surrogate marker is to a target.
gold_rationale: This case illustrates a surrogate outcome trap: the treatment (X) successfully moves a biomarker (Y) toward a numeric target, but does so by overshooting into a harmful range that causes symptomatic hypoglycemia (Z). The apparent success on the lab value encourages the mistaken belief that the patient is healthier, even though the true risk profile may be worse. Statistically, evaluating only changes in HbA1c ignores adverse events and other clinical endpoints, so the correlation between intensive treatment and "better" numbers does not imply improved overall health. Proper causal assessment requires examining whether the intervention reduces meaningful outcomes (e.g., mortality, severe hypoglycemia), not just optimizing the surrogate marker.

The trial was not double-blind, and the physician repeatedly told participants that this was a 'very strong and promising new drug.' Pain scores were collected using self-reported 0–10 scales at clinic visits.
claim: The experimental painkiller clearly reduces pain by 30% and should be approved based on its strong pharmacologic effect.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z→Y, X→Y? (psychological expectation drives outcome; true drug effect unclear)
key_insight: Because the trial is unblinded and the doctor’s enthusiasm shapes expectations, the observed pain reduction may be largely placebo-driven rather than a true pharmacologic effect of the drug.
hidden_timestamp: Because the trial is unblinded and the doctor's enthusiasm shapes expectations, the observed pain reduction may be largely placebo-driven rather than a true pharmacologic effect of the drug.
answer_if_condition_1: If the mediating variable (Doctor’s enthusiastic suggestion/expectation (Psychological co-intervention)) began changing before Experimental painkiller (Treatment), the association is confounded by pre-existing conditions.

wise_refusal: Unblinded trials confound the drug’s pharmacologic effect with expectation and placebo effects. The physician’s strong positive framing can itself reduce self-reported pain, especially for subjective outcomes. Without a blinded control group in which neither patients nor clinicians know who receives the drug, we cannot separate the effect of the molecule from the effect of suggestion. Regulatory or clinical decisions should rely on double-blind, placebo-controlled data, not on these biased estimates.
gold_rationale: This scenario mixes two causal pathways into the same outcome: the experimental drug’s pharmacologic action (X→Y) and the doctor-induced expectation effect (Z→Y). Because the trial is unblinded and the clinician explicitly boosts expectations, Z is tightly linked to X, making it impossible to tell whether X has any true biological effect beyond placebo. The naive analysis attributes the entire 30% improvement to X, ignoring that similar improvement might occur if patients received an inert pill with the same enthusiastic framing. Proper inference requires a blinded, placebo-controlled design to block the Z→Y path and isolate the specific effect of X.

scenario: A small open-label trial tests a new topical gel for eczema. Participants know they are receiving the "latest breakthrough treatment," and their dermatologist enthusiastically tells them, "This gel has been working wonders for my patients." After four weeks, 70% of participants report that their itching is "much improved" on a 10-point subjective symptom scale.
claim: The company concludes that the gel itself is highly effective for eczema because 70% of users reported substantial symptom relief.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z→Y with X and Z confounded (unblinded administration)
key_insight: Without blinding, subjective symptom improvements can be driven by expectation and suggestion rather than the pharmacologic action of the gel.
hidden_timestamp: Without blinding, subjective symptom improvements can be driven by expectation and suggestion rather than the pharmacologic action of the gel.
answer_if_condition_1: If the mediating variable (Patient and clinician expectations/suggestion (Ambiguous Variable)) began changing before New eczema gel (Treatment), the association is confounded by pre-existing conditions.
answer_if_condition_2: If Patient and clinician expectations/suggestion (Ambiguous Variable) changed only after New eczema gel (Treatment), this supports a causal pathway from treatment to outcome via the mediator.
wise_refusal: Because the trial was unblinded and both patients and the dermatologist expected benefit, the observed symptom relief may largely reflect expectation and placebo effects rather than the true efficacy of the gel. Subjective outcomes like itch intensity are especially susceptible to this bias. To attribute the 70% improvement to the gel itself, we would need a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study where neither patients nor clinicians know who receives the active product.
gold_rationale: This scenario mixes the pharmacologic effect of the gel (X) with expectation-driven placebo effects (Z) on a subjective outcome (Y). In an unblinded design, knowing one is on the "breakthrough" treatment and receiving enthusiastic messages from the clinician can directly lower symptom reporting (Z→Y), independent of any true biologic effect. Because there is no blinded control group, we cannot separate X→Y from Z→Y, so the naive causal inference that the gel is highly effective is unwarranted. Proper blinding and placebo control are needed to identify the gel's specific effect beyond expectation bias.

scenario: Among patients who completed a 12‑month randomized clinical trial, those assigned to the experimental drug had significantly better health outcomes at 12 months than those assigned to placebo. Investigators highlight this as strong evidence that the experimental drug is superior, and base their efficacy estimate only on these completers.
claim: "Because outcomes among trial completers were better on the experimental drug than on placebo, this per‑protocol comparison proves the drug is more effective than placebo."
label: NO
causal_structure: X→Z←Y (treatment assignment and patient outcome both influence probability of completing the trial)
key_insight: Conditioning on trial completion selects a biased subset of patients because reasons for dropping out differ between treatment arms, turning completion into a collider between treatment and outcome.
hidden_timestamp: Conditioning on trial completion selects a biased subset of patients because reasons for dropping out differ between treatment arms, turning completion into a collider between treatment and outcome.
answer_if_condition_1: If the analysis conditions on a common effect of both Experimental drug assignment (Treatment) and Health outcome at 12 months (Outcome), the observed association is spurious (collider bias).
answer_if_condition_2: If the analysis does not condition on variables affected by both Experimental drug assignment (Treatment) and Health outcome at 12 months (Outcome), the association may reflect a true causal relationship.
wise_refusal: Per‑protocol analyses that only include patients who complete follow‑up condition on a collider—trial completion. Patients may drop out of the experimental arm due to side effects or early worsening, and drop out of the placebo arm for different reasons, so the subset who remain is not comparable across arms. We should instead use an intention‑to‑treat analysis that includes all randomized patients, regardless of completion, or explicitly model time‑to‑dropout as a competing process. Without that, we cannot reliably attribute the better outcomes among completers to the drug’s true efficacy.
gold_rationale: Randomization balances prognostic factors at baseline, but conditioning on post‑randomization variables like completion breaks that balance. Completion status is affected by both treatment assignment (e.g., side effects in the experimental arm) and evolving health status, so restricting to completers opens a backdoor path X→Z←Y and induces spurious associations. As a result, the observed difference among completers can be exaggerated, attenuated, or even reversed relative to the true causal effect. A valid estimate of treatment efficacy should be based on intention‑to‑treat or appropriate causal methods (e.g., inverse probability weighting) that account for differential dropout without conditioning on the collider itself.

scenario: A large COVID-19 treatment trial followed patients for 6 months. Among participants who remained in the study for the full 6 months, those randomized to Antiviral B had a 20% hospitalization rate, while those on placebo had a 35% hospitalization rate. However, many patients in the placebo arm who deteriorated early were withdrawn and started on open-label rescue therapies, and several patients in the Antiviral B arm stopped the drug due to side effects and were also withdrawn from follow-up.
claim: Because patients who completed the full 6‑month protocol on Antiviral B had fewer hospitalizations than completers on placebo, Antiviral B clearly reduces the risk of hospitalization.
label: NO
var_X: Randomization to Antiviral B vs placebo (Treatment)
var_Z1: Completion of 6‑month follow-up on assigned therapy (Collider)
var_Z2: Reasons for dropout (e.g., early deterioration, side effects) (Mechanism of selection)
causal_structure: X→Z←Y (treatment arm and health status both affect trial completion, which is conditioned on)
key_insight: Restricting analysis to participants who complete follow‑up conditions on a collider, creating a biased subset that can make one arm look better even if the treatment has no true benefit.
hidden_timestamp: Restricting analysis to participants who complete follow-up conditions on a collider, creating a biased subset that can make one arm look better even if the treatment has no true benefit.
answer_if_condition_1: If the analysis conditions on a common effect of both Randomization to Antiviral B vs placebo (Treatment) and Hospitalization within 6 months (Outcome), the observed association is spurious (collider bias).
answer_if_condition_2: If the analysis does not condition on variables affected by both Randomization to Antiviral B vs placebo (Treatment) and Hospitalization within 6 months (Outcome), the association may reflect a true causal relationship.
wise_refusal: Focusing only on patients who completed the 6‑month protocol is a per‑protocol analysis that conditions on trial completion, which is influenced by both treatment assignment and clinical outcome. Patients on placebo who became very sick were more likely to drop out early for rescue treatment, and patients on Antiviral B who had side effects also discontinued, so the remaining "completers" in each arm are a biased subset. This conditioning on a common effect (completion) creates collider bias and can spuriously suggest benefit. A valid estimate of Antiviral B’s effect requires an intention‑to‑treat analysis that includes all randomized patients regardless of completion or protocol adherence.
gold_rationale: This scenario illustrates collider bias from per‑protocol analysis. Trial completion (Z) is affected both by treatment assignment (X)—through side effects or tolerability—and by outcomes or early clinical deterioration (Y), which lead to dropout or rescue therapy. Conditioning on Z (analyzing only completers) opens a noncausal path X→Z←Y, inducing an artificial association between X and Y even if the true causal effect is null. The correct approach is an intention‑to‑treat comparison of all randomized participants, which preserves randomization and avoids conditioning on post‑randomization colliders.

scenario: Among hospitalized patients, those diagnosed with Disease A are observed to have substantially lower rates of Disease B than would be expected based on general population data. A research team analyzes only this inpatient dataset and reports that having Disease A appears to protect against developing Disease B.
claim: "Disease A seems to protect against Disease B, since among hospitalized patients, those with Disease A have lower rates of Disease B than expected."
label: NO
causal_structure: X→Z←Y (both diseases increase the chance of hospitalization; conditioning on Z induces a spurious association between X and Y)
key_insight: Restricting analysis to hospitalized patients conditions on a collider (hospital admission), which can create an artificial negative association between two diseases that actually occur independently or even positively together in the general population.
hidden_timestamp: Restricting analysis to hospitalized patients conditions on a collider (hospital admission), which can create an artificial negative association between two diseases that actually occur independently or even positively together in the general population.
answer_if_condition_1: If the analysis conditions on a common effect of both Has Disease A (Exposure) and Has Disease B (Outcome), the observed association is spurious (collider bias).
answer_if_condition_2: If the analysis does not condition on variables affected by both Has Disease A (Exposure) and Has Disease B (Outcome), the association may reflect a true causal relationship.
wise_refusal: Hospital-based studies that only include admitted patients condition on hospital admission, which functions as a collider when multiple diseases independently increase the chance of being hospitalized. This conditioning can induce a spurious negative association between Disease A and Disease B, even if there is no true protective effect. To infer anything about whether Disease A protects against Disease B, we would need data from a sample not selected on hospitalization status, or use appropriate methods to account for this selection mechanism.
gold_rationale: Both Disease A and Disease B increase the probability of being hospitalized, so hospitalization lies on the arrow from each disease (X→Z and Y→Z). When we restrict the analysis to hospitalized patients (condition on Z), we open a non-causal path between Disease A and Disease B that induces a negative correlation: if a patient is already in the hospital because of Disease A, they are less likely (within this selected group) to also have Disease B as a cause of admission, and vice versa. This is Berkson's Paradox, a classic collider bias, not evidence that Disease A biologically protects against Disease B. Proper causal inference requires analyzing an unselected population or modeling the selection process explicitly, rather than drawing conclusions from the inpatient sample alone.
