wise_refusal: The association reflects selection on wealth and engagement rather than a biological effect of the devices.
gold_rationale: SES confounding makes optional health technologies appear causally beneficial when they are markers of better care.

scenario: Cancer patients taking Supplement S (X) had longer survival rates (Y). These patients also had higher socioeconomic status (Z).

hidden_timestamp: If Wealth Confounds: Wealthy patients (Z) afford better standard care, nutrition, and the supplement (X). The supplement is a marker of resources, not a cause of survival.

scenario: ICU patients who received emergency dialysis had higher mortality rates than ICU patients who did not. These patients also had markedly worse kidney failure scores prior to dialysis initiation.

label: NO

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If severity worsened only after dialysis, the procedure may have caused harm.

wise_refusal: This is classic confounding by indication. Dialysis is used for the most severe cases, so mortality reflects baseline risk, not treatment harm.
gold_rationale: Patient severity drives both dialysis use and death, making dialysis appear dangerous when it is a response to critical illness.

gold_rationale: Confounding by indication makes life-saving support appear harmful when severity is not accounted for.

gold_rationale: Conf Med (Spontaneous Remission Confounding) applies: Natural immune response may precede and confound treatment

scenario: Patients screened with New Test T (X) survived 5 years longer (Y) after diagnosis than those screened with the Old Test. Test T detects tumors at Stage 1 (Z), while Old Test detects at Stage 3.
claim: The new screening test increases survival because screened patients live longer.
label: NO
causal_structure: Earlier clock start, not longer life
key_insight: Longer survival later death
hidden_timestamp: Did the age at death change, or only the duration of known illness (Y)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Lead-Time Only: The test (X) detects disease earlier (Z), starting the survival clock sooner. The patient dies at the same age but “survives” longer post-diagnosis. This is an illusion.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If True Benefit: If the age at death is delayed (patients live to 75 vs. 70), the earlier detection (Z) enabled curative treatment.

wise_refusal: Longer post-diagnosis survival does not prove benefit. If patients die at the same age regardless of test, the ‘survival’ improvement is lead-time bias. We need data on age at death, not survival post-diagnosis.” 2.8
gold_rationale: Conf Med (Lead-Time Bias) applies: Longer survival later death

scenario: Patients who received a Heart Transplant (X) lived significantly longer (Y) than pa- tients who were placed on the waiting list but did not receive a heart. 6
claim: Receiving a transplant causes longer survival compared with those who did not receive one.
label: NO
causal_structure: Must survive wait to receive treatment
key_insight: Treatment receipt requires survival during waiting period
hidden_timestamp: How do we account for patients who diedwhile waitingfor the transplant?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Bias Present: To receive a transplant (X), a patientmustsurvive the waiting period (Z). They are ”immortal” during the wait. Patients who die early are classified as ”No Transplant,” artificially lowering the survival of the control group.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the key timing/structure is reversed: Then the intervention may plausibly drive the mediator/variable and affect the outcome; assess with appropriate controls or design.

wise_refusal: This comparison suffers from Immortal Time Bias. Transplant recipients had to survive the waiting list to get the treatment. We must treat transplant status as a time-dependent covariate to avoid guaranteeing survival for the treated group during the wait.” 2.9
gold_rationale: Selection (Immortal Time Bias) applies: Treatment receipt requires survival during waiting period

scenario: Patients treated with Antibiotic Z (X) have a higher death rate (Y) than those on Antibiotic A. Antibiotic Z is reserved for Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR) infections (Z).
claim: Antibiotic Z increases mortality compared with Antibiotic A.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z → XandZ → Y
key_insight: Last-resort drugs treat last-resort cases
hidden_timestamp: Was the resistance profile (Z) confirmedbeforeDrug Z was selected?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If t Z< tX(Indication Bias): MDR infections (Z) are inherently more deadly. An- tibiotic Z is reserved for these cases. Higher mortality reflects the infection type, not drug toxicity.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If Drug is Toxic: If Drug Z shows higher mortality even in non-MDR cases, the drug may have toxicity issues.

wise_refusal: Last-resort antibiotics are given to the sickest patients with resistant organisms. Higher mortality reflects patient selection, not drug failure. We need resistance-stratified analysis.” 2.10
gold_rationale: Selection (Confounding by Indication) applies: Last-resort drugs treat last-resort cases

scenario: Runners wearing Shoe Brand H (X) reported higher rates of knee injury (Y). These runners log significantly higher weekly mileage (Z) than average.
claim: Shoe Brand H causes knee injuries.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z → X, Y(serious runners choose specific gear)
key_insight: Shoes are markers of training intensity
hidden_timestamp: Did the injury rate (Y) increaseafterswitching to Brand H, controlling

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If t Zdominates (Mileage is Confounder): Serious runners (Z) choose Brand H (X) and also get injured (Y) due to volume. The shoe is a marker of training intensity.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If Shoe is Causal: If injury rates rose after switching brands, controlling for mileage, the shoe may be problematic.

wise_refusal: High-mileage runners self-select into specific brands. Without controlling for training volume, we cannot attribute injuries to the shoe. Please provide mileage-adjusted injury rates.” 2.11
gold_rationale: Selection (Training Volume Confounding) applies: Shoes are markers of training intensity

scenario: Patients reporting severe migraines (Y) were found to have consumed chocolate (X) recently. These patients were in the ‘Prodrome’ phase (Z) of a migraine attack.
claim: Eating chocolate triggers migraines.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z → X(prodrome causes craving)
key_insight: Cravings are symptoms, not triggers
hidden_timestamp: Did the craving (X) startafterthe biological onset of the attack (Z)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If t Z< tX(Prodrome causes craving): The migraine’s prodrome phase (Z) causes cravings for sweet/fatty foods (X). Chocolate is asymptomof the impending migraine, not a cause.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If t X< tZ(Chocolate triggers migraine): If chocolate was consumed days before prodrome onset, it may be a trigger.

wise_refusal: This is classic protopathic bias. The prodrome phase causes food cravings before pain onset. Chocolate consumption may be a symptom of the impending attack, not a trigger. Please clarify the timing of consumption relative to prodrome onset.” 2.12
gold_rationale: Reverse (Protopathic Bias) applies: Cravings are symptoms, not triggers

scenario: People who floss daily (X) live 3 years longer (Y). These people also exercise regularly and don’t smoke (Z).
claim: Flossing daily causes people to live longer.
label: NO
causal_structure: Personality → X, Z, Y
key_insight: Flossing is a marker of conscientious personality
hidden_timestamp: Does the correlation hold for smokers who floss?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Conscientiousness Confounds: Flossing (X) is a marker for conscientiousness per- sonality trait (Z). Conscientious people do everything right (exercise, diet, don’t smoke), extending life (Y). Flossing itself may add nothing. 10
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If Flossing is Causal: Flossing reduces oral bacteria linked to cardiovascular disease. The biological pathway is direct.

wise_refusal: Flossing is bundled with other healthy behaviors. Without controlling for exer- cise and smoking, we cannot isolate flossing’s effect. Please provide data on flossers who smoke.” 2.13
gold_rationale: Selection (Conscientiousness Confounding) applies: Flossing is a marker of conscientious personality

scenario: Teenagers using Cream C (X) saw their acne clear up (Y). These patients also passed the age of 19 (Z) during treatment.
claim: Cream C caused the acne to clear.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z → Y(natural hormonal resolution)
key_insight: Acne resolves naturally with age
hidden_timestamp: Did the clearing (Y) coincide with the birthday (Z) or the treatment start

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If t Zdominates (Maturation): The hormonal phase ended naturally (Z), clearing acne (Y). The cream (X) was applied during natural remission.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If t Xworks: If clearing began immediately after cream application, before age mile- stones, the cream has effect.

wise_refusal: Acne naturally resolves with hormonal maturation. Attributing clearance to the cream requires showing the cream works faster than natural resolution. Please compare treatment timing to age-related remission curves.” 11 2.14
gold_rationale: Conf Med (Maturation Threat) applies: Acne resolves naturally with age This case demonstrates a clear causal reasoning pattern that requires careful analysis of the underlying mechanisms.

scenario: Seniors who got the Flu Shot (X) had lower all-cause mortality (Y) during winter. These seniors were mobile enough to travel to the clinic (Z).
claim: Flu vaccination reduces all-cause winter mortality.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z → X, Y(baseline health determines both)
key_insight: Vaccine recipients are healthier at baseline
hidden_timestamp: Did the mortality difference existbeforeflu season started?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Frailty Confounds: Those who skipped the shot were too frail (Z) to leave home and more likely to die (Y) regardless of flu. The shot (X) is a marker of baseline health.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If Shot is Protective: If the mortality gap appears only during flu season and disap- pears in summer, the shot has specific protective effect.

wise_refusal: Frailty bias inflates vaccine effectiveness. Seniors who get vaccinated are health- ier at baseline. We need pre-season mortality data to separate frailty selection from vaccine effect.” 2.15
gold_rationale: Selection (Frailty Bias) applies: Vaccine recipients are healthier at baseline

scenario: Athletes drinking Shake S (X) recovered faster (Y) from injury. They also increased their protein intake (Z) from whole foods. 12
claim: Protein shake S uniquely speeds recovery compared with other protein sources.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z → Y(total protein matters, not source)
key_insight: Protein is fungible across sources
hidden_timestamp: Did recovery speed (Y) improve only when the shake (X) was added, or

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Total Protein Matters: Recovery (Y) depends on total protein (Z). The shake (X) is one source. Whole foods would work equally well.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If Shake has Specific Benefit: If the shake contains compounds beyond protein (BCAAs, timing advantages), it may have independent effect.

wise_refusal: Protein shakes are often added alongside dietary improvements. Without con- trolling for total protein intake, we cannot attribute recovery to the shake specifically.” 2.16
gold_rationale: Conf Med (Total Intake vs. Specific Product) applies: Protein is fungible across sources

scenario: Patients on Med M (X) saw their blood pressure stabilize (Y). However, they also reported frequent dizziness (Z).
claim: Medication M improves health because it stabilizes blood pressure.
label: NO
causal_structure: X → overcorrection → Z
key_insight: “Stable” may mean dangerously low
hidden_timestamp: Did the dizziness (Z) correlate with pressure dips below normal range?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Overtreatment: The “stability” (Y) is actually dangerous hypotension. Dizziness (Z) signals the drug (X) is overcorrecting. The outcome is harm, not benefit.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If Side Effect: Dizziness (Z) is an independent side effect, unrelated to the BP mech- anism.

wise_refusal: Dizziness during BP treatment may signal overtreatment. If ‘stable’ readings are below safe thresholds, the drug is causing hypotension, not health. Please clarify absolute BP values.” 2.17
gold_rationale: Conf Med (Overtreatment / Surrogate Outcome) applies: “Stable” may mean dangerously low

scenario: Patients undergoing Knee Replacement (X) reported a 50% reduction in pain (Y). These patients also adhered to a strict Physical Therapy regimen (Z).
claim: Knee replacement surgery caused the pain reduction.
label: NO
causal_structure: X → Z → Y(PT as mediator) orZ → Yindependently
key_insight: PT may work without surgery
hidden_timestamp: Did the patient start the PT regimen (Z)beforethe surgery date?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If t Z< tX(PT is Confounder): PT (Z) may have reduced pain (Y) independently. Surgery (X) may be unnecessary if PT alone works.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If t X< tZ(PT is Mediator): Surgery (X) requires PT (Z) for recovery. The surgery is the root cause; PT is the mechanism of benefit.

wise_refusal: Co-interventions confound surgical outcomes. If PT began before surgery, PT may deserve credit. If PT is mandatory post-surgery, it is a mediator. Please clarify whether PT preceded or followed the operation.” 2.18
gold_rationale: Conf Med (Co-Intervention Confounding) applies: PT may work without surgery

scenario: Participants taking the experimental painkiller (X) reported 30% less pain (Y). The trial was not double-blind, and the doctor told them it was ‘very strong’ (Z).
claim: The experimental drug reduced pain by 30%.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z → Y(expectation drives subjective outcome)
key_insight: Unblinded trials confound pharmacology with psychology
hidden_timestamp: Did the pain relief (Y) startbeforethe drug could biologically be absorbed?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Placebo: The doctor’s suggestion (Z) created expectation of relief. If pain dropped before pharmacokinetics allow (instant relief), it is purely placebo.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If Drug Works: If relief coincides with expected drug absorption timing, the chemical has effect.

wise_refusal: Unblinded trials confound drug effects with placebo effects. The doctor’s sugges- tion biases patient reporting. Without a blinded control group, we cannot separate pharmacology from expectation.” 2.19
gold_rationale: Conf Med (Expectation Bias / Placebo) applies: Unblinded trials confound pharmacology with psychology

scenario: Among patients who completed (Z) a 12-month clinical trial, those on the experimental drug (X) had better outcomes (Y) than those on placebo.
claim: Among trial completers, the experimental drug is superior to placebo.
label: NO
causal_structure: X → Z←Y(dropout reasons differ by arm)
key_insight: Completers are a biased sample
hidden_timestamp: Are we conditioning on trial completion (Z)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If we condition on the selected subgroup: Patients drop out of trials due to side effects (drug arm) or lack of efficacy (placebo arm). Conditioning on completion (Z) excludes drug patients who had bad reactions and placebo patients who deteriorated. The “completers” are a biased sample. The drug may look better because its failures dropped out.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If we analyze without conditioning on selection: If we do not condition on the collider/selected sample (e.g., use intention-to-treat or population-level analysis), the spurious association should weaken or disappear.

wise_refusal: Per-protocol analysis conditions on completion, which is a collider. Patients drop out for different reasons in each arm. Intention-to-treat analysis (including dropouts) is required for valid comparison.” 2.20
gold_rationale: Collider (Per-Protocol vs. Intention-to-Treat) applies: Completers are a biased sample

scenario: Among hospitalized patients (Z), those with Disease A (X) have lower rates of Disease B (Y) than expected from population data.
claim: Disease A protects against Disease B.
label: NO
causal_structure: X → Z←Y(both diseases cause hospitalization)
key_insight: Hospital-based studies create spurious correlations
hidden_timestamp: Are A and B independent causes of hospitalization?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If we condition on the selected subgroup: Both Disease A and Disease B independently cause hospitalization (Z). Among hospitalized patients, having A “explains away” why they are hospitalized, making B less likely conditional onZ. This is spurious negative correlation. In the general population, A and B may be independent or even positively correlated.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If we analyze without conditioning on selection: If we do not condition on the collider/selected sample (e.g., use intention-to-treat or population-level analysis), the spurious association should weaken or disappear.

wise_refusal: Hospital-based studies condition on admission, which is a collider when multiple diseases cause admission. The apparent negative association between diseases A and B is Berkson’s Paradox, not a biological relationship.” 2.21
gold_rationale: Collider (Berkson’s Paradox) applies: Hospital-based studies create spurious correlations

scenario: A clinician summarizes the evidence: among hospitalized patients (Z), those with Disease A (X) have lower rates of Disease B (Y) than expected from population data.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If we condition on the selected subgroup: Both Disease A and Disease B independently cause hospitalization (Z). Among hospitalized patients, having A “explains away” why they are hospitalized, making B less likely conditional onZ. This is spurious negative correlation. In the general population, A and B may be independent or even positively correlated.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If we analyze without conditioning on selection: If we do not condition on the collider/selected sample (e.g., use intention-to-treat or population-level analysis), the spurious association should weaken or disappear.

scenario: Among published studies (Z), Drug D (X) shows a 40% improvement over placebo (Y).

label: NO

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If we condition on the selected subgroup: Studies are published (Z) if they show positive results (Y) or are methodolog- ically important. Null results go in the file drawer. The 40% effect is inflated by publication bias. The true effect, including unpublished trials, is likely smaller.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If we analyze without conditioning on selection: If we do not condition on the collider/selected sample (e.g., use intention-to-treat or population-level analysis), the spurious association should weaken or disappear.

wise_refusal: Published literature conditions on publication, which selects for positive results. Meta-analyses of published studies overestimate treatment effects. We need data from trial registries to include unpublished null results.” 2.22
gold_rationale: Collider (Publication Bias) applies: The file drawer contains null results

label: NO

scenario: Patients prescribed Antidepressant D (X) in March showed significant mood improve- ment (Y) by May. Daily hours of sunlight (Z) increased by 3 hours during this period.
claim: The antidepressant caused the mood improvement observed from March to May.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z → Y(seasonal remission) The relationship requires careful causal analysis to avoid spurious conclusions.
key_insight: Spring cures SAD regardless of medication
hidden_timestamp: Does the improvement curve (Y) match the sunlight curve (Z) regardless

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If t Zdominates (Seasonal Confounding): Spring sunlight (Z) cures Seasonal Affec- tive Disorder (Y). The drug (X) is riding the seasonal wave.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If t Xdominates (Drug Works): If patients starting in October also improve by December (when sunlight is decreasing), the drug (X) has independent effect.

wise_refusal: Prescribing antidepressants in March confounds drug effect with seasonal re- covery. To isolate the drug’s effect, we need data on patients starting treatment in autumn when sunlight is decreasing.” 2.25
gold_rationale: Conf Med (Seasonal Confounding) applies: Spring cures SAD regardless of medication This case demonstrates a clear causal reasoning pattern that requires careful analysis of the underlying mechanisms.

scenario: In a nursing home population, patients with higher cholesterol (X) are observed to live longer (Y) than those with low cholesterol. A doctor prescribes a high-fat diet to extend life.

label: NO
causal_structure: Terminal illness (Z) causes weight loss and low cholesterol (X)
key_insight: Low cholesterol in the elderly is often a marker of dying
hidden_timestamp: Did frailty/terminal illness precede low cholesterol, making low cholesterol a marker of declining health?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If outcome/prodrome precedes exposure: This is reverse causation/protopathic bias; X is a symptom/response to Z.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If exposure clearly precedes onset and mechanism supports: Then X could be a true cause.

wise_refusal: Prescribing a high-fat diet (X) is misguided. This ’Reverse Epidemiology’ paradox occurs because terminal illness and frailty (Z) often cause weight loss and plummeting cholesterol levels before death. High cholesterol is a marker of relative robustness in this specific population, not a cause of longevity.” 2.26
gold_rationale: Reverse (Survival Bias / Frailty) applies: Low cholesterol in the elderly is often a marker of dying

label: NO

claim: Drug W caused the weight loss.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If t X< tZ(Drug causes appetite suppression): The drug (X) suppresses appetite, causing calorie deficit (Z), causing weight loss (Y). The drug works via the mechanism of appetite. This is a valid mediator.

wise_refusal: If the caloric reduction preceded the drug, the weight loss is diet-driven. If the drug caused the appetite change, it works via appetite suppression. Please clarify whether the dietary change followed drug initiation.” 2.32

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If t Z< tX(Indication Bias): Doctors use the procedure (X) on the sickest patients (Z). The procedure appears to “cause” death because it is given to those already dying. This is confounding by indication.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If t X< tZ(Both contribute): The prescription (X) and diet counseling (Z) started together. Effects are additive but inseparable.

wise_refusal: Co-interventions are common in cardiovascular medicine. If diet preceded the statin, diet may deserve credit. If both started simultaneously, their effects are confounded. Please clarify the sequence.” 2.34
gold_rationale: Conf Med (Co-Intervention) applies: Lifestyle changes often accompany prescriptions

scenario: Couples undergoing IVF Treatment (X) had a 30% conception rate (Y). These couples also reported significantly reducing workplace stress (Z).
claim: IVF treatment caused the conception success.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z → YorY → Z(success causes relaxation)
key_insight: Stress reduction may be cause or consequence of success
hidden_timestamp: Did the stress reduction (Z) beginbeforethe successful cycle?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If t Z< tX(Stress is Confounder): Reducing stress (Z) may have enabled natural conception or improved IVF odds. The lifestyle change (Z) deserves partial credit.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If t X< tZ(IVF Success enables relaxation): After successful implantation (Y), couples relax (Z). The stress reduction is a consequence, not a cause.

wise_refusal: The stress-fertility relationship is bidirectional. If stress reduction preceded the successful cycle, it may have contributed. If relaxation followed success, it is a consequence. Please clarify the timing.” 2.35
gold_rationale: Conf Med (Bidirectional Stress-Fertility Relationship) applies: Stress reduction may be cause or consequence of success

scenario: Patients reporting ”Peak” chronic back pain (Z) were prescribed Pill X (X). One week later, they reported a 40% reduction in pain (Y).
claim: Pill X caused the rapid pain reduction.
label: NO
causal_structure: Selection at extreme → guaranteed regression
key_insight: Treatment at peak guarantees apparent improvement
hidden_timestamp: Do patients with peak pain (Z) improve spontaneously (Y) without treat-

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Regression to Mean: Chronic pain fluctuates. Patients seek help only when pain is at its peak (Z). Statistically, the next measurementmustbe lower (Y) even with a placebo. The drug takes credit for natural fluctuation.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the key timing/structure is reversed: Then the intervention may plausibly drive the mediator/variable and affect the outcome; assess with appropriate controls or design.

wise_refusal: Treating at the peak of symptoms introduces ‘Regression to the Mean.’ Patients naturally improve from extreme states. Without a control group that also started at peak pain, we cannot distinguish drug effect from natural fluctuation.” 2.36
gold_rationale: Selection (Regression to the Mean) applies: Treatment at peak guarantees apparent improvement

scenario: Heart failure patients taking Supplement A (X) had longer survival rates (Y). These patients also had higher socioeconomic status (Z).
claim: Supplement A caused heart failure patients to live longer.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z → X, Y(wealth drives both) The relationship requires careful causal analysis to avoid spurious conclusions.
key_insight: Supplements are markers of resources, not causes of survival
hidden_timestamp: Is survival (Y) correlated with wealth (Z) in the non-supplement group?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Wealth Confounds: Wealthy patients (Z) afford better standard care, nutrition, and the supplement (X). The supplement is a marker of resources, not a cause of survival.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If Supplement Independent: If survival improves even in low-SES supplement users, the supplement may have biological effect.

wise_refusal: Socioeconomic status confounds supplement studies. Wealthy patients have better baseline care. Unless the supplement shows benefit after stratifying by income, we cannot attribute survival to the supplement.” 2.31
gold_rationale: Selection (Healthy User Effect / SES Confounding) applies: Supplements are markers of resources, not causes of survival

scenario: Patients prescribed Sleep Aid E (X) in March showed significant mood improvement (Y) by May. Daily hours of sunlight (Z) increased by 3 hours during this period.
claim: The sleep aid caused the mood improvement observed from March to May.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z → Y (seasonal remission) The relationship requires careful causal analysis to avoid spurious conclusions.
key_insight: Spring cures SAD regardless of medication
hidden_timestamp: Does the improvement curve (Y) match the sunlight curve (Z) regardless

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Z dominates (Seasonal Confounding): Spring sunlight (Z) cures Seasonal Affective Disorder (Y). The drug (X) is riding the seasonal wave.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If X dominates (Drug Works): If patients starting in October also improve by December (when sunlight is decreasing), the drug (X) has independent effect.

wise_refusal: Prescribing sleep aids in March confounds drug effect with seasonal recovery. To isolate the drug’s effect, we need data on patients starting treatment in autumn when sunlight is decreasing.” 2.25
gold_rationale: Conf Med (Seasonal Confounding) applies: Spring cures SAD regardless of medication This case demonstrates a clear causal reasoning pattern that requires careful analysis of the underlying mechanisms.

scenario: A retrospective cohort study compares mortality between heart failure patients who eventually received Drug M and those who never did. Patients are classified as “treated” from cohort entry if they received Drug M at any point during follow-up. Because patients had to survive long enough to receive Drug M, the treated group includes a period of guaranteed survival before treatment initiation.
claim: The drug reduces mortality in heart failure patients.
label: NO

Z: Immortal person-time prior to treatment initiation

causal_structure: Misclassified person-time: treated group includes time when outcome could not occur.
key_insight: Survival before treatment is incorrectly attributed to treatment effect.
hidden_timestamp: Was there a period during which patients classified as treated could not yet experience the outcome?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If exposure is modeled as time-varying and immortal time is correctly assigned to the untreated group, the apparent benefit may disappear.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If treatment were assigned at baseline (or randomized), survival differences could be interpreted causally.

wise_refusal: I can’t infer a causal treatment effect without correcting for immortal person-time and modeling exposure timing properly.
gold_rationale: This is Immortal Time Bias (T4). Patients must survive to receive treatment, so early survival is guaranteed and wrongly credited to the drug. Proper time-aligned or time-varying analysis is required.

scenario: A cross-national study finds that countries with higher average rates of antidepressant use also have higher average suicide rates. Commentators claim that antidepressant use increases suicide risk. However, the analysis uses country-level averages and does not examine whether individuals who take antidepressants are more likely to die by suicide within countries.
claim: Antidepressant use increases suicide risk
label: NO

Z: Population composition and healthcare access differences

causal_structure: Group-level correlation between X̄ and Ȳ does not imply the same relationship holds at the individual level.
key_insight: Associations observed across groups can reverse or disappear within groups.
hidden_timestamp: Does the relationship between antidepressant use and suicide hold among individuals within the same country?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If individual-level data show antidepressant users have higher suicide risk after adjustment, the claim may hold.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If within-country individual data show lower or no increased suicide risk among users, the group-level claim is invalid.

wise_refusal: I can’t infer individual causal effects from country-level correlations without individual-level analysis.
gold_rationale: This is an Ecological Fallacy (T6). Country-level correlations between antidepressant use and suicide reflect compositional differences, reporting practices, or healthcare access—not individual treatment effects. Inferring individual risk from aggregate data is invalid.

scenario: A hospital implements a patient education program to reduce heart attacks by encouraging individuals to lower dietary cholesterol. Despite high participation, heart attack rates do not decline. Subsequent evidence shows that most heart attacks in this population are driven by chronic inflammation and hypertension rather than dietary cholesterol levels.
claim: The patient education program failed because dietary cholesterol does not cause heart attacks.
label: NO
causal_structure: Intervention targets M1, but true causal pathway runs through M2 to Y.
key_insight: Interventions fail when they block a mechanism that is not causally responsible for the outcome.
hidden_timestamp: Did the intervention successfully block the actual causal mechanism leading to heart attacks?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If inflammation or blood pressure mediates most heart attacks, targeting cholesterol education alone will not reduce incidence.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If dietary cholesterol is a dominant causal pathway in this population, the intervention could plausibly work.

wise_refusal: I can’t conclude the intervention is ineffective without evidence about which biological mechanisms actually cause heart attacks in this population.
gold_rationale: This is a T15 Mechanism error. The intervention targets an incorrect or incomplete causal pathway, leaving the true causes of the outcome unblocked. Failure does not imply the outcome is immutable, only that the wrong mechanism was targeted.

scenario: A hospital introduces a policy tying physician bonuses to achieving a low average emergency department door-to-needle time for stroke patients. After implementation, reported door-to-needle times fall sharply, and administrators claim stroke care quality has improved. However, clinicians begin delaying the formal “stroke diagnosis” timestamp or diverting complex cases to other hospitals to meet the metric, while patient outcomes do not improve.
claim: Lower door-to-needle times improved stroke outcomes
label: NO
causal_structure: Metric M no longer reliably tracks outcome Y once it becomes a target.
key_insight: When a proxy metric becomes a target, behavior shifts to optimize the metric rather than the true outcome.
hidden_timestamp: Is the performance metric being manipulated or gamed once incentives are attached?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If reduced times reflect genuine process improvements and outcomes improve, the metric remains valid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If clinicians alter documentation or patient selection without outcome gains, the metric has broken under Goodhart’s Law.

wise_refusal: I can’t infer improved care quality without evidence that patient outcomes improved alongside the metric.
gold_rationale: This is Goodhart’s Law (T16). Once door-to-needle time became an incentive target, staff optimized the metric rather than care quality, breaking the link between the proxy and true outcomes.

scenario: A public health campaign introduces graphic warning labels on sugary drinks to reduce consumption and obesity. Surveys later find that heavy consumers report drinking more sugary beverages, and critics argue the warnings backfired. Follow-up research shows that some individuals react defensively, dismiss the warnings, or increase consumption as an expression of autonomy.
claim: The warning labels increased sugary drink consumption
label: NO
causal_structure: Intervention I triggers compensatory behavior C that offsets or reverses the intended effect on Y.
key_insight: Interventions can provoke behavioral responses that counteract their intended goals.
hidden_timestamp: Could the warning labels trigger reactance or compensatory behavior among targeted individuals?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If consumption decreases after accounting for reactance-prone subgroups, the intervention may still be effective overall.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If reactance dominates and consumption rises among key groups, the intervention backfires.

wise_refusal: I can’t conclude the intervention is harmful without separating direct effects from compensatory responses.
gold_rationale: This is a Backfire Effect (T17). The intervention provoked reactance, leading some individuals to increase the very behavior it aimed to reduce, reversing the intended effect.

scenario: A hospital mandates that inpatient units reduce average length of stay (LOS) and ties compliance to departmental evaluations. After implementation, average LOS falls, and leadership claims care efficiency improved. However, clinicians begin discharging patients earlier and increasing readmissions, while overall patient outcomes do not improve.
claim: Reducing length of stay improved patient outcomes
label: NO
causal_structure: Metric M (LOS) stops tracking outcome Y once optimized directly.
key_insight: Optimizing a proxy metric can decouple it from the true outcome it was meant to measure.
hidden_timestamp: Did clinicians change discharge behavior primarily to meet the LOS metric rather than improve care?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If LOS reductions coincide with stable or improved outcomes, the metric remains valid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If readmissions rise without outcome improvement, the metric has been gamed and broken.

wise_refusal: I can’t infer improved care quality without evidence that reduced LOS improved patient outcomes.
gold_rationale: This is Goodhart’s Law (T16). Once LOS became a target, staff optimized discharge timing rather than recovery, breaking the proxy–outcome relationship.

scenario: A city mandates calorie labels on fast-food menus to reduce obesity. Follow-up surveys show some consumers order higher-calorie items after noticing the labels, interpreting them as signals of better value or indulging deliberately. Critics argue the policy worsened dietary choices.
claim: Calorie labeling increased unhealthy food consumption
label: NO
causal_structure: Intervention triggers compensatory behavior C that offsets intended effect on Y.
key_insight: People may rationalize unhealthy behavior after exposure to health information.
hidden_timestamp: Could calorie labels prompt compensatory indulgence among certain consumers?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If overall calorie intake falls after labeling, the intervention may still be beneficial.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If compensatory indulgence dominates, the intervention backfires.

wise_refusal: I can’t conclude the policy is harmful without separating direct effects from compensatory responses.
gold_rationale: This is a Backfire Effect (T17). Exposure to calorie information can trigger moral licensing, increasing consumption among some individuals.

scenario: A vaccination campaign emphasizes social responsibility and community protection. In response, some individuals report reduced adherence to other preventive behaviors, such as mask-wearing, believing vaccination alone makes precautions unnecessary.
claim: Increased vaccination messaging reduced overall disease risk
label: NO
causal_structure: Intervention I induces compensatory behavior C that counteracts intended reduction in Y.
key_insight: Safety interventions can prompt offsetting increases in risky behavior.
hidden_timestamp: Could vaccination messaging reduce adherence to other protective behaviors?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If preventive behaviors remain unchanged while vaccination rises, net risk may fall.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If risk compensation offsets vaccination benefits, the intervention backfires.

wise_refusal: I can’t infer net risk reduction without accounting for compensatory behavior changes.
gold_rationale: This is a Backfire Effect (T17). Emphasizing protection can lead to reduced caution elsewhere, offsetting intended public health gains.
